moves.1. e4: Hey, this seems like an interesting game to study and discuss. I'll put some initial comments, pls feel free to expand the analysis and correct me where I'm wrong :)
moves.1... c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nc6: Inaccuracy, I believe. What is the purpose or threat of this move? A common plan here is a6-Qc7-b6-Bb7, making the 'hedgehog'
moves.10... Nc6: How do Nd7 and Ng6 look? Nd7-c5 seems both reasonable and threatening.
moves.11. g4: No need to be intimidated by white's pawn rush. This is to be expected in this opening most of the time anyway. What is a natural reaction to a side attack like this?
moves.11... Ne8: This is probably a mistake, giving in to imaginary threats. The correct reaction I believe was e5: when facing attack on the side, start your own game by opening up the center!
moves.12. a3: I am not sure what is white doing. Waiting for black's plan?
moves.14... e5: ! good defensive move, in the spirit of the position: wait till opponent gets too ambitious and then counterattack!
moves.15. Nf5: Is this a mistake? Seems to be losing a pawn to Bxf5 16. exf5 exf4 17. Bxf4 Bxg5. In view of that, I'd play Nxc6
moves.15... g6:
Is this a mistake? Black could have won a pawn?

Also they say when facing a pawn assault, don't move your own pawns that are being attacked, unless tactically necessary. It only creates weak squares.
moves.17. h4: Here it feels like a critical position for black to try and get some counter-initiative or at least exchange some pieces. How is f6? Or exf4 followed by Ne5 and Ne6? Straight Ne6?
moves.20. Nd5: This knight is strong, I'd just try to exchange it with Nc7
moves.24... Qf8: It was probably good idea to try to exchange both d5 knight and f7 bishop
